image.altText: A man in a suit shreds a piece of paper in a shredder

props.synopsis: Australia votes "yes" to a resolution in the United Nations General Assembly on Friday backing a Palestinian bid to become a full member of the organisation by recognising it as qualified to join.

title.children: Israel's ambassador shreds copy of UN charter before pro-Palestinian General Assembly vote

image.altText: A female soldier in a helmet and face covering

props.synopsis: Seven months into this war, Israeli authorities have not eliminated Hamas, they have not freed the hostages and they have not restored national security.

title.children: 'There's only been losers and we need to cut our losses': How does Israel actually end this war?

image.altText: Aerial shot of dozens of houses in neat rows in a new outer-suburban housing estate.

props.synopsis: Billions more will be committed to building new homes in next week's federal budget, as the government chases a promise to build 1.2 million by the end of the decade.

title.children: Government to tip billions more into housing in next week's federal budget

image.altText: A black sign with green letters reading "For Lease, Apartment 1".

props.synopsis: The ATO says landlords are falling foul of tax rules, but one landlord says it's only human to 'claw back' something from the government.

title.children: The ATO is moving to weed out tax-evading landlords, as it reveals very high rates of tax return errors

image.altText: A man in a suit holds a phone up, captured from above on CCTV.

props.synopsis: Zheming Zhang was granted conditional bail in the ACT Magistrates Court after his arrest last week.

title.children: Man pleads not guilty to impersonating Chinese police officer after allegedly extracting $400,000 from international student in Canberra

image.altText: A man smiles for the camera

props.synopsis: The ACT Supreme Court heard from a pre-sentence report about the man, who cannot be named as he was 17 when the crime was committed.

title.children: Shooter who killed man at his doorstep in 'case of mistaken identity' 'loves doing crime', court hears

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann leaves Federal Court in Sydney, surrounded by people, looking serious

props.synopsis: Federal Court Justice Michael Lee on Friday ordered Bruce Lehrmann to pay costs of a higher order than typically seen in defamation cases, but also declared there were "no real winners" in the multi-million-dollar legal battle.

title.children: What happens if Bruce Lehrmann can't afford to pay the massive legal bill coming his way

image.altText: Andrew Giles speaks at a press conference at parliament house

props.synopsis: A bid to give the immigration minister extraordinary new powers to deport people and ban others from coming to Australia hangs in the balance, with government and opposition locked in a stand-off.

title.children: 'The ball is in their court': Coalition lists its demands to pass Labor immigration changes

image.altText: Donald Trump's former lawyer and fixer Michael Cohen smiles as he arrives for a second day of testimony before a grand jury.

props.synopsis: Michael Cohen was once Trump's personal attorney and said he would "take a bullet" for his boss, so what happened to make him flip?

title.children: Michael Cohen has destroyed his life trying to put Donald Trump in jail. Here's why he flipped on his former boss

image.altText: A photo of a person in an online meeting with the person's head is blurred.

props.synopsis: The ANU has promised to take swift action if an investigation finds Nazi gestures were used at an online students' association meeting this week.

title.children: Australian National University investigating if Nazi gestures were used at student association meeting

image.altText: A woman standing in front of large green leaves smiles

props.synopsis: The single mother exercised regularly and had good blood pressure. It was a shock to wake up in the middle of the night feeling something "catastrophic" was happening.

title.children: Rowena went to bed exceptionally tired. In the middle of the night, she woke to her heart fluttering

image.altText: Two men in suits walking under a tree with orange leaves in the courtyard of Parliament House.

props.synopsis: A few days before the budget there's a bit of a "too many notes" feeling to the Albanese government's current suite of issues in play and, sadly, not all of it is ingenious or quality.

title.children: You can only judge a budget once you've seen the whole thing, but there's already a feeling of 'too many notes'

image.altText: A woman wearing a headscarf and a serious expression looks off-camera.

props.synopsis: Widespread alcohol addiction has frayed the social fabric of Alice Springs. But frontline services fear a far greater threat is looming in the outback town – meth.

title.children: Fears of new Alice Springs crime wave as children start using meth

image.altText: A big blue circle with a bright orange blog on the bottom right.

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology warned level G4 (severe) geomagnetic storm conditions were expected to arrive at Earth from about 8pm AEST on Friday.

title.children: BOM warns of severe geomagnetic storms over weekend

image.altText: Mother sits on bed holding toy koala up to phone during video call with her children

props.synopsis: Healthcare staffing shortages have led a small Australian town to recruit a Filipino workforce.

title.children: Filipino workers on temporary visas live in tiny rural towns away from their children to take care of our elderly

image.altText: A shot of coastal cliffs with some wild forest above.

props.synopsis: The unauthorised boat arrival was detected in Australian waters early on Thursday morning with those on board originally taken by Border Force to Christmas Island before being transferred to another offshore facility.

title.children: Boat carrying 33 suspected asylum seekers intercepted in Australian waters

image.altText: A woman with brown hair points angrily at a board displaying flights as she speaks to another woman.

props.synopsis: Airlines in the United States will soon be held to clear and consistent standards on flight cancellations, delays or unexpected changes to a passenger's travel plans. So what lessons could these new rules hold for Australia?

title.children: Australians often 'fight tooth and nail' for refunds after cancelled flights. Could that soon change?

image.altText: A fisherman casts his rod as storm clouds pass over Botany Bay in Sydney

props.synopsis: As NSW is soaked by another bout of rain, updated modelling further raises the prospect of La Niña's return in 2024.

title.children: Weekend washout edges Sydney towards multiple rain records as La Niña looms on the horizon

image.altText: Tristed metal and tin on the partially collapsed PCYC building in Bunbury

props.synopsis: Two people are rushed to hospital after a tornado smashes through Bunbury on Friday afternoon.

title.children: Two hospitalised as tornado rips through WA's south-west, tearing off roofs and damaging property

image.altText: Two boys and a girl sit happily holding a viola, cello and trumpet. Their mum and dad sit next to them.

props.synopsis: Music industry heads say families are cutting back on music classes as the cost-of-living crisis bites, while teachers are leaving the profession due to the drop in participation. What does this mean for the future of the industry?

title.children: Why this family refuses to give up music lessons, despite the cost-of-living crunch

image.altText: A graphic shows an outline of Kim Jong Un against blue, red and white, stripes with hands holding aloft mobile phones.

props.synopsis: A lively propaganda anthem glorifying Kim Jong Un as the "Friendly Father" of the country is meant to help shape a softer image for the dictator and it's been massively popular around the world.

title.children: 'Best K-pop since Gangnam style': North Korea's propaganda anthem is a 'banger' and it's going off on social media

image.altText: A woman in a bandaged-style dres sings into a microphone on a stage with an Israeli and a Russian flag either side of her.

props.synopsis: The European Broadcasting Union excluded Russia from the 2022 Eurovision Song Contest after the country invaded Ukraine, so why is Israel still participating in 2024?

title.children: Why is Israel allowed to participate in Eurovision even though Russia was banned?

image.altText: Bambie Thug looks at the camera with a fierce facial expression as a dance leans backwards

props.synopsis: The international spectacle that is the Eurovision Song Contest is wrapping up this weekend. You'll have to set your alarm to catch it — or stay awake until the wee hours of Sunday.

title.children: Eurovision's grand final starts very early on Sunday morning in Australia. Here's how to watch it

image.altText: Teenage girl stands with horse

props.synopsis: As hundreds of wild horses are shot from the air in Kosciuszko National Park, brumbies further north are experiencing the "cushy" perks of domestic life.

title.children: The brumbies being 'transformed' from wild horses as they find new homes

image.altText: man and woman hugging and smiling on the couch

props.synopsis: Sexologist's research shows sex can get better as we age — and a lot of that is to do with prioritising intimacy, being generous, and working with what you've got.

title.children: Eating after and exercising before: Sexologist's top tips for lovemaking in later years

image.altText: A hand hugging a bowl of lentil soup with potato and spinach. On the table are lemons, cumin and sea salt.

props.synopsis: Shorbat Adas bil Hamed is a traditional Lebanese lentil soup with a zesty lemon kick.

title.children: This lentil, lemon and potato soup is delicious — and good for you, too

image.altText: A white teenage boy with fair hair and Down syndrome sitting on the ground

props.synopsis: Remembering their son Finlay brings smiles to his parents' faces — but the pain of losing him to what they believe was a preventable death is undeniable.

title.children: Finlay was screaming as he arrived at hospital — but staff 'rolled their eyes' and didn't see him for hours

image.altText: Nat Fyfe and Alex Pearce in tears during tribute

props.synopsis: Fremantle coach Justin Longmuir reveals some players were in doubt to feature in Friday night's 48-point loss to Sydney following the sudden death of former Docker Cam McCarthy.

title.children: 'Incredibly challenging': Grieving Dockers band together as they remember former teammate McCarthy

image.altText: Nathan Cleary looking upset as he walks to the Panthers team bus.

props.synopsis: Star playmaker Nathan Cleary injures his hamstring in the Panthers' 16-10 win over the Bulldogs, less than a month out from the State of Origin series opener.

title.children: 'Shattered' Cleary in doubt for State of Origin as Blues face injury crisis

image.altText: Caramelo the brazilian horse

props.synopsis: A Brazilian horse nicknamed Caramelo by social media users garnered national attention after a television news helicopter filmed him stranded on a rooftop in southern Brazil, where massive floods have killed more than 100 people.

title.children: Caramelo, the Brazilian horse stranded on a roof by floods, is rescued after stirring the nation

image.altText: a STILL of the ad that shows a hydraulic press crushes an array of creative instruments.

props.synopsis: Apple says it "missed the mark" in its new advertisement for the iPad Pro, which involves using a hydraulic press to crush a large collection of creative instruments.

title.children: Apple apologises for crushing musical instruments in new iPad Pro advertisement

image.altText: Taylor Swift singing passionately into a microphone, in a white dress shaking her head

props.synopsis: Given Swift's been playing pretty much the same show since March last year, fans knew the set list and costumes. But there were new songs and outfits for Swifties in Paris.

title.children: Taylor Swift played her first concert since releasing a new album. Here are the new outfits
